titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vassar College Dean of Students Records, 1877-2003 (bulk 1887-1992)
titlestmt.author: Inventory prepared by Laura Streett

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Laura Streett, 2009

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Vassar College Dean of Students Records

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries

did.abstract: Materials relating to student life, campus facilities, admissions, events, as well as other student life and general administrative issues.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The current Office of the Dean of Students "oversees and coordinates the Office of Residential Life, Counseling Service, Health Services, International Services and the array of faculty, administrative, and student personnel who assist in the residence halls... In addition, the dean supervises the student fellow program—recruiting, training, and coordinating the activities of student fellows." Although the name has changed several times, the office was created at the founding of the college. The Lady Principal was the first college official to deal with student life and the rules and regulations of the college. The initial charge of the principal was ensure that students personal, moral and spiritual needs were being tended. She acted as an academic and personal advisor, oversaw student housing, and presided over most social events. The responsibilities of the office have changed in the succeeding decades, but the main focus is still student life.

chronitem.event: Vice President for Administrative and Student Affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, memoranda, minutes, questionnaires, blueprints and architectural drawings relating to student life, campus facilities, admissions, events, as well as other student life and general administrative issues. The records contain much information about changes in student regulations and the concept of in loco parentis.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Boxes 7 and 8 contain records restricted to the office of origin due to student and personnel privacy issues. The rest of the collection is open for research according to the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Permission to quote (publish) from unpublished or previously published material must be obtained as described in the regulations of the Vassar College Archives and Special Collections Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also the Lady Principal records in the

controlaccess.head: VCL Categories
controlaccess.subject: Vassar College Administrative Offices and Functions

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Dean of Students office and its predecessors in several accessions.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Vassar College Dean of Students Records, Archives and Special Collections Library, Vassar College Libraries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in 4 series. The first 3 are based loosely on the various titles of the office, although there is much overlap. The fourth is a 2014 accession of material on the House Fellow program.

scopecontent.p: The Mixed Records series includes materials from the offices of the Lady Principal, the Warden, the Dean of Residence, and the Vice President for Student Affairs.

did.unittitle: Series II. Vice President for Student Affairs,

scopecontent.p: Materials relating to the duties of the Vice President that related to admissions.

did.unittitle: Series III. Vice President for Administrative and Student Affairs,

scopecontent.p: Subject files kept by the VP for Administrative and Student Affairs, although some materials date to earlier incarnations of the office.
Materials documenting the founding and growth of the House Fellow Program.
See also, the folders in boxes 2 and 6, which contain material dating from 1947-1959 and 1978-1989.
Please note that the bulk of material dating after 1961 is currently restricted.
